Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can close a PDA. Prostaglandin E1 infusion is used to keep a PDA open when the neonate is dependent on the shunt for cardiac output. Surgical ligation and percutaneous surgery are other treatment options for PDA closure, but these are typically reserved for cases when indomethacin is ineffective or contraindicated.

Treatment for PDA depends on the size of the PDA and the clinical presentation of the patient. In this case, as the patient is asymptomatic and the PDA is not causing significant hemodynamic compromise, a trial of indomethacin infusion would be the most appropriate first-line treatment. Prostaglandin E1 infusion would be used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus in cases of ductal-dependent congenital heart defects. Surgical ligation and percutaneous surgery would be indicated if medical therapy fails or if the patient develops significant symptoms.

Indomethacin is used to close a PDA in infants weighing less than 1500 g, and surgical ligation is reserved for infants who fail medical therapy or have contraindications. Prostaglandin E1 infusion would be used in another situation, such as in a neonate with congenital heart block. Percutaneous surgery is not a commonly used option for PDA closure in infants.
